G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the claims presented pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, and this is an action to recover damages for personal injuries caused by the negligence of the Defendant.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the acts or omissions giving rise to this cause of action occurred in Lowell, Massachusetts.

**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.proposition: - **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (establishing duty of care owed to invitees);
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case that abolished the traditional invitee/licensee distinction and imposed a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners to all lawful visitors, including former licensees. While the provided excerpt is from a concurrence discussing trespassers, the majority opinion clearly establishes the duty of care owed to invitees (and extends it to licensees) as a matter of Massachusetts law. Thus, citing Mounsey for the proposition that it establishes the duty of care owed to invitees is accurate.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.relevant_excerpt: We hold that the obligation of reasonable care which the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors is the same, regardless of whether they are business visitors or social guests. The common law distinctions between invitees and licensees, as they have developed in this Commonwealth, are hereby abolished. Henceforth the duty of care owed by the occupier to such persons is to act as a reasonable man in all the circumstances.

**Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148.proposition: - **Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) (liability for dangerous conditions foreseeably caused by another’s actions);
**Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landowner can owe a duty to remedy an open and obvious danger where the landowner has created and maintained that danger knowing lawful entrants would foreseeably encounter it despite the risk. The court emphasizes that the defendants set up and maintained the trampoline–pool configuration specifically to facilitate the risky use that caused the injury and knew it was dangerous, yet did nothing to change it. That reasoning directly supports liability for dangerous conditions foreseeably caused by another’s (here, the landowner’s) affirmative actions.
**Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148.relevant_excerpt: “Because we conclude that a landowner has a duty to remedy an open and obvious danger, where he has created and maintained that danger with the knowledge that lawful entrants would (and did) choose to encounter it despite the obvious risk of doing so, we now reverse…. Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool…for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool…. The defendants knew that it was unsafe to do so and, therefore, could or should have anticipated injuries resulting from this activity.”

**O'Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2.proposition: - **O'Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2000) (duty to warn or remedy open and latent dangers);
**O'Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2.support_reasoning: The case squarely concerns the duty of landowners to warn of dangerous conditions, but it expressly limits that duty by holding that there is no duty to warn of open and obvious dangers. The court does not recognize any general duty to warn or remedy both open and latent dangers; instead, it affirms a duty to warn only of ‘unreasonable dangers’ that are not open and obvious, and holds that an open and obvious danger is duty‑negating. Thus, citing this case for a broad duty to warn of open as well as latent dangers misstates its holding.
**O'Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2.relevant_excerpt: “This duty includes an obligation to ‘maintain[ ] his property in a reasonably safe condition…’ and ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’… Moreover, it is well established… that a landowner’s duty to protect lawful visitors against dangerous conditions on his property ordinarily does not extend to dangers that would be obvious to persons of average intelligence… Landowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises….”

**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.proposition: - **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368 (2010) (exercise of reasonable care to prevent harm to patrons);
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that Massachusetts law governing snow and ice hazards is governed by the same general premises-liability duty of reasonable care owed to lawful visitors. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and replaces it with a requirement that property owners act as a reasonable person under all the circumstances to protect lawful visitors from snow and ice hazards—i.e., to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm to patrons. Thus, it directly supports citing the case for that proposition.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards. … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.raw_text: **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.**, 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.proposition: - **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.**, 448 Mass. 780 (2007) (constructive notice of dangerous conditions);
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.support_reasoning: The case does not apply or develop the traditional constructive notice doctrine for dangerous conditions; instead, it expressly moves away from requiring constructive (or actual) notice proven by the duration a hazard was on the floor. The court adopts the mode-of-operation approach, under which the store’s chosen self-service operation itself can satisfy the notice requirement through foreseeability, rather than constructive notice in the traditional sense. Thus, citing Sheehan as authority for ordinary constructive notice of dangerous conditions is inaccurate; it is authority for the mode-of-operation/foreseeability substitute for notice.
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement.”

**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.proposition: - **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (1980) (balancing foreseeability and preventive measures in establishing negligence);
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely adopts a general negligence standard for landlords, expressly framed in terms of weighing the likelihood and seriousness of injury against the burden of preventing it. The court quotes with approval a formulation that a landlord must act as a reasonable person "including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk," which is exactly a balancing of foreseeability and preventive measures in determining negligence. Thus the case is properly cited for that proposition.
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. We think this basic principle of responsibility for landlords as for others ‘best expresses the principles of justice and reasonableness upon which our law of torts is founded’” (citations omitted).

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2.proposition: - G.L. c. 93A, § 2 (addressing unfair or deceptive acts in commerce, though referenced here for context);

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7 3.proposition: - G.L. c. 143, § 3 (duties regarding safe building conditions);

**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.proposition: - **Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) (standards of reasonable care).
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.support_reasoning: The opinion contains a clear, general statement of the negligence standard and of the landowner’s duty framed explicitly in terms of reasonable care. The court explains that negligence is measured by what an ordinarily prudent person would do under the circumstances and that the landowner must maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, while not being required to provide maximum safety. This directly supports citing the case for standards of reasonable care.
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.relevant_excerpt: “Negligence, without qualification and in its ordinary sense, is the failure of a responsible person, either by omission or by action, to exercise that degree of care, vigilance and forethought which, in the discharge of the duty then resting on him, the person of ordinary caution and prudence ought to exercise under the particular circumstances…. Ordinarily, where a duty of care is established by law, the standard by which a party’s performance is measured is the conduct expected of an ordinarily prudent person in similar circumstances. The same standard is frequently expressed in terms of ‘reasonable care’…. Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’”}
